comments.commentBody: I am moving to Switzerland.
This is a good idea.

Neil, with this kind of generalization you could argue that Americans are so guilt-ridden by the fact that their country is the only industrialized democracy that still has the death penalty that the whole country has been over-eating to forget and is now obese; which is obviously a stupid statement! Or were you just joking?
Do the animals have to be Swiss citizens?
This is ridiculous...seriously someone needs to draw the line on where animal rights, certain other types of activism etc becomes stupid...the line definitely has been crossed in this instance

brooms out!
clean sweep!
all incumbents resign or lose.

He'll have plenty of company
Gillibrand definitely
Schumer we can only hope
Bush vs. Gore did not further a "political objective." Yeah right!\

Nice try, David, but I'm not buying your specious comparison of two cultures that existed in different times. It was the awful bloody war in Vietnam and the draft that stoked the fires of the left. Today's tea paritiers could care less about the blood being spilled in Iraq and Afghanistan. In fact, most of them are middle-aged, potbellied, and white men who want more war, not less.

The activists of the 60s were mainly students intelligent enough to discern the truth from the lies that spewed from mouths of the generals and Washington war hawks. Today's right wing loonies are mainly ignoramuses who believe anything and everything the Fox News lie machine puts out.

David, your statement that conservatism is based on the assumption of human fallibility and uncertainty and that conservatives believe in civilization is just too laughable. To assert that Dick Cheney, Carl Rove, and Donald Rumsfeld et al believe in their fallibility and uncertainty is akin to asserting that God is an atheist. And how many thousands of lives have been sacrificed at the Republican altar of preemptive invasions of countries the Bush administration hated and feared. Some civilized leadership that was!

"To remedy our fallen condition, conservatives believe in civilization — in social structures, permanent institutions and just authorities, which embody the accumulated wisdom of the ages and structure individual longings."When the "social structures" and "permanent institutions"become so rotten and cynical, as the gov'ts of LBJ and RMN became,people must turn to civil disobedience.Our gov't turned a generation into cynics who believed in nothing but money,because it was money that kicked our butts when we were young.And now money(through it's custodians) has let us down and the Tea Party will now bury us in anger and class warfare as we fade into retirement.

A minority of self-serving, short-term-thinking, and vile-minded politicians, egged on and supported by a similarly motivated constituent minority are bottle-necking progress. They are emboldened by the inaction of the rest of us. They know we are feeble. I am now of a mind that dramatic direct action is needed. Voting doesn't do it. Letter writing, phone calls, and emails don't do it. There remains only one thing that these people have any regard for and it is our work and our shopping. It is time for general strikes and selective boycotts.
Carl, Portland

I don't know why anyone should be surprised that Republicans are willing to throw us all under the bus for political points.  It's what they have always done.  What's unfortunate is that the Democrats waste time and effort trying to reason with them.  Each day they spend trying to redeem the unredeemable, real people suffer.  Let them suffer long enough, and you lose their support -- exactly what the Republicans are counting on.

Well, we're saving boatloads by not prosecuting the former administration for war crimes; surely some of that money could be used to keep a lock on the newly-minted criminals who, on account of the destroyed economy those same war criminals left behind them, are having trouble finding a way to pay for their bread.

Maybe the budget crisis will finally force us to decriminalize drugs and treat it as a health problem and not a crime.  And why are they releasing violent criminals when they have even one person in jail for possession?
The last time this occurred in the 1970's and 1980's there was a crime wave in this country, get ready for another one !

It would cost the average California taxpayer $32 a year to restore funding to K-12, community colleges, CSU and UC to its 2000 levels.  That's the amount of money we're talking about.  Do we seriously think the investment is not worth it?  This knee jerk opposition to taxes of any sort muddles the conversation.  The amount per person is trivial.  The cost of disinvestment astronomical.

Another sweet Friday, my favorite puzzle day. Second best clue: Cruise vehicle. Brilliant. Conceived in a nonstandard way is a nice sneaky one too. I had to admit defeat on torn and pasted paper, even though Arp shows up a lot.

very interesting. people choose to put shocking or immoral videos on the web, thinking that they can remain anonymous, but then their identities are publicly disclosed.

then they regret their behavior?

it is fascinating that we behave and even think differently in an anonymous or private setting versus in public. context is so important. for example, relatively few of us choose to have sex in public (although the plethora of sex videos on the web makes this statement debatable), but we do it and like it in private all of the time. i wonder why.

it is also interesting how we instinctively “pile-on” perceived transgressors, ostracizing them or worse based on our conception of a group identity. what is it about the human brain that makes us want to lord over others and take power of a group?

and the best quote of the article: “When we tried to fight evil, we found ourselves becoming evil.” (cf., George Orwell (1945), "Animal Farm".)

Unlike you, I believe the differences between the two groups are greater than their similarities.

The protesters of the sixties were by and large young and naive. The Tea Party demonstrators are, in the main, much older, much more experienced.

The young leftists were living in a time when conformity ruled, and they wanted to break the bonds of what they saw as fossilized social norms in order to create a new, freer society in which all individuals were valued. They fought for civil rights, not imagining the masses were innocent and would do better without government strictures. They worked for legislation that would have government institutionalize racial equality. The older people on the right are living in a society where pretty much anything goes. They seem to want to fight the government not in order to ensure rights for all, but to keep what they have. If you listen to them speak, you soon learn they don't believe people (aside from themselves) are pure and virtuous. The one thing they seem to want from government is protection from the evil other and the right to arm themselves.

Yes, the tactics of both groups may be the same, and on the surface they both seem to be anti-establishment, but to dismiss both groups as being self-righteously naive, to gloss over their different agendas, is be self-righteous and naive yourself. There is a big difference between protesting against bad government and protesting against government. The founding fathers knew that, and so did a lot of us sixties "radicals."

David,

You leave out three criticial differences of the Right today: religion and race are blatant sub-texts wrapped in the selfishness of a " what's mine is mine "
attitude.

David, sometimes I think you are living in an alternative universe.  The "movement" of the 60s was so intellectually and morally superior to the Tea Party movement they practically don't belong on the same planet, let alone in the same essay.  The Movement of the 60s wasn't against all structure, all authority.  Born really out of the Civil Rights movement, it was mainly against injustice and the ABUSE of authority and the intransigence of an Old-Boy dominated structure.  It had definable and reasonable goals.  The Tea Party movement, which I prefer to call the Soup Kitchen movement because they want government to butt out of the economy and let the second great depression just happen, are really the last gasp of those calcified pre-60s institutions.  They are also born out of the Civil Rights movement, but are on the opposite end of the spectrum.  When it comes down to it, the Tea Partiers are fueled by an irrational rejection of the first African American President.  That's why the John Birch Society supports them - remember Bill Buckley's expose of the John Birch Society's virulent racism, way back when Conservatives were part of polite society?

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
A certain grain of innocence pre-dates even the infamous '60s.

Americans famously were the people who, in coming to the original colonies, and crossing the mountains, were throughout its history rejecting and leaving establishments. Sometimes this was done in innocence -- all the utopian communities of Hawthorne's time, and many more since -- before the '60s.

But when Jefferson argued for rejecting establishments, he did so in some good wisdom as to farming, and nurturing the land. He wasn't just an innocent. Not all who object to establishments automatically are at all naive.

I've been often in touch on this with fellow "commenter" Cdr. John Newlin, over in Vista Point, California. He feels strongly that all Americans "are" the establishment, are fully part of all the problems -- and so no one can really run away, even as innocently as you imagine, or you imagine others imagine. I think Cdr. John's right. All get it from all corporate ed. There's no running away from so many of the habits of Corporate America that at too many levels are too ingrained in all.

Now, if only Americans had some education to allow seeing how much so many are part of the probllem -- rather than the light-hearted scoffing as you indulge today on innocents.

With due respect to the previous two comments, I think they are confusing contemporary U.S. conservatives
(Cheney et. al. who are in fact right wing radicals) with Mr. Brooks' classical conservatives. From that perspective, it is at least thought provoking to make the connection between Tea Partyistas and 60's street politics. More like the hippies in Central Park, then the anti-war movement, and certainly not like the Civil Rights Movement. In any case, it is a posthumous slur on the fun-loving, funny Abbey Hoffman to compare him with the unfunny striver, Glen Beck. For all of his faults, Hoffman cared about other people, Beck does not.
"...it seems as though the ’60s political style will always be with us...."  Like adolescent rebellion.  Part of growing up and finding out that original sin is on the inside, not the outside.

I found this article reassuring. Since the legacy of the 60's leftist radicals was the era of the conservative Nixon, perhaps the legacy of the right-wing Tea Partiers will be ensuring a liberal Presidency for the next few elections.
